title: Ticket #7670: Python bindings daemon objects should know their own address
description:
Python bindings daemon objects (like Collector and Schedd) should expose enough information to re-locate them. For instance, I should be able to do something like 

c1 = Collector("some-address")
c2 = Collector(c1.address)

or 

s1 = Schedd()
s2 = Schedd(s1.address)

(One difference between these is that the Collector constructor takes a string, but the Schedd needs a location ad... perhaps we can unify the API while we're at it? Related: #7668)

Internally, this is probably necessary for doing the per-daemon locking that will be part of the followup to #7359 .
remarks:
2020-May-29 15:51:08 by karpel:
TJ notes that there might be some complications in the protocol. From my perspective, the important things are:

  1. I should be able to make a fresh instance using information available on an existing instance.
  2. I should be able to uniquely identify a daemon based on information available on an instance.

2020-Jun-01 08:27:16 by bbockelm:
Would it be OK if the "location information" was kept opaque instead of a human-readable address? There's some value to push to keep the sinful string as an "implementation detail" as possible.

Alternately, a daemon's contact details is really the tuple of (collector, type, name); what if we exposed that?

2020-Jun-01 08:32:26 by karpel:
Right - I don't want the internal representation (sinful), I want the "Pythonized" address so that I can do Python stuff to it. Returning a tuple (or even better, a named tuple https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html#collections.namedtuple or equivalent) of contact details would be fine.

2020-Jun-26 09:41:57 by johnkn:
Daemon contact details are not (collector, type, name) - that's what you use to do a locate query. But most daemons are actually constructed from address files.

The contact details are (sinful, version), that's what you get from an address file, and also the important part of what you get back from a locate query.

2020-Jul-14 10:43:04 by johnkn:
notes from a conversation between TJ and Josh:

Daemon.location() or Daemon.location, second form is preferable location is a named tuple or equivalent so you can do location.address like JobEvent.cluster

The location tuple must have an address (sinful) member, is should have a version member.

All daemon object constructors should be able to take a Location, or a daemon ad.

Location must be hashable and comparable

Location object may contain a member that is the collector query tuple needed to refresh the address and version fields, this tuple consists of (collector,type,name)

Probaby should be a sub-ticket, but some daemon objects should also have a directQuery member, for example 

    htcondor.Startd(collector.locate(...)).directQuery(...)
    htcondor.Startd(location).directQuery(...) for location in collector.locate(...)

also maybe this? 

    daemon.directQuery(...) for daemons in collector.locate_daemons(...)
